column1: See also United States v. Lassiter, 816 F.3d 1288, 1291 (D.C. Cir. 2016) (“[T]he district court did not err in concluding that the government had established that the defendant had used a firearm during and in relation to a crime of violence.”).

See also United States v. Lassiter, 825 F.3d 125, 128 (D.C. Cir. 2016) (per curiam) (affirming conviction of defendant who pled guilty to kidnapping, assault with intent to kill while armed, and using a firearm during a crime of violence); United States v. Lassiter, 812 F.3d 1

See also United States v. Lassiter, 859 F.3d 1111, 1114 (D.C. Cir. 2017) (“[T]he district court did not err in concluding that the government had not met its burden of proving that the firearm was used in connection with a crime of violence.”).

See also United States v. Lassiter, 859 F.3d 126, 130 (D.C. Cir. 2017) (“[T]he district court did not err in finding that the government had established that the defendant had used a firearm during and in relation to a crime of violence.”).
